Award.AwardTitle: AGS-PRF: Aerosols in Shallow Tropical Convection: Impact on Cloud Microphysics and Precipitation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Atmospheric aerosols are very small particles that are suspended in the air. Many are comprised of dust, smoke or sea salt from the Earth's land and ocean surfaces, while others are formed through chemical reactions in the atmosphere. Aerosols likely play a role in forming clouds and precipitation, but the relative importance of aerosols versus other mechanisms is unclear. The impact of aerosol forcing on the climate system remains one of the largest unknowns in the atmospheric science community. This Postdoctoral Research Fellowship will allow an early-career researcher the opportunity to study the role of aerosols in shallow tropical convection and precipitation. The project will be a combined observational and theoretical exercise, with analysis of research aircraft data and studies making use of an advanced numerical model. Better knowledge of how aerosols affect clouds and precipitation would have a significant impact on understanding of the weather and climate system, leading to better forecasts. The researcher also plans to conduct mentoring and outreach, thereby enhancing public understanding of science.

Observational evidence from the DOMEX (Dominica Experiment) field campaign shows a strong relationship between aerosol and cloud number concentration, cloud droplet size, and surface precipitation amount. This relationship will be further explored using aircraft observations from past and planned field campaigns along with numerical model simulations. The project will be carried out as a combination of two separate but closely related studies. The first is a bulk statistical approach with a large number of in-situ aircraft observations. The second is a theoretical study on microphysical processes and rates of cloud and precipitation formation using the Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model. The researcher will work in close collaboration with the author of one of the main microphysical schemes used in the WRF model.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aerosols are tiny gas, liquid, or solid particles in our atmosphere. Dust, smoke, fog, sea spray, and plant matter are examples of some commonly known aerosols. Aerosols affect how clouds and precipitation form and evolve, which has profound implications for ecosystems and climate. The impact of aerosol on climate remains one of the largest unknowns in atmospheric science.

 

Clouds are composed of an uncountable number of tiny water droplets. Aerosols affect when, where, and the rate that these droplets form and combine with eachother, which has effects on the formation and evolution of the cloud itself, the amount of precipitation that forms, and where the precipitation falls. This NSF postdoctoral research fellowship has helped to advance understanding within the sub discipline of atmospheric science involving indirect aerosol effects, meaning that the study is focused on clouds, which are affected by aerosols.

 

The fellowship project was designed to advance knowledge of the role of aerosols in shallow tropical convection and precipitation. Prior observational evidence from the DOMEX (Dominica Experiment) field campaign showed a strong relationship between aerosol and cloud number concentration, cloud droplet size, and surface precipitation amount. A numerical model called WRF (Weather Research & Forecasting model) was used to further explore this relationship over an island mountain. It was found that the impact of aerosols on shallow clouds in a mountainous setting is highly dependent on the environment. If the atmospheric environment was moist and had sufficient vertical lifting such that it was going to rain, adding aerosols to that environment changed little about the ultimate rain produced. However, in an atmospheric environment where a cloud may or may not form rain, adding aerosols suppressed rain formation.

 

In addition to the above primary project, work was also focused on two other fronts.  First, datasets of cloud observations collected previously by aircraft projects were compared to observe the spread in cloud droplet sizes and cloud droplet number concentrations. The observations were compared based on height, temperature, location, vertical wind speed, horizontal wind speed, and other parameters. It was found that the spread in observations due to instruments changing over time was larger than the spread in observations due to differences in clouds. Further work will be needed to control for these instrument changes in order to extract useful results. The second project front was a study on how sea spray, or large sea salt aerosols grow through condensation in a shallow cloud. It was shown that the conventional wisdom applied to condensational growth does not apply in the case of sea salt aerosols because their salt content makes them extremely hygroscopic or hydrophilic. Instead, large sea salt aerosols grow much more rapidly by condensation than other types of aerosols due to this solute effect.

 

Shallow clouds, both trade-cumulus clouds, stratocumulus clouds, or shallow continental cumulus clouds are ubiquitous around the globe and account for a significant portion of precipitation globally. Understanding how aerosols affect clouds and precipitation is really important, especially given the current environmental changes, both by industrialization and by changing global temperature patterns. We cannot hope to understand the future environment if we cannot fully understand our current environment.

 

The broader impacts beyond science from the project include the following: (1) improvements to our understanding of how aerosols affect clouds and precipitation will lead to improved forecasting of weather and climate, and (2) the fellowship had significant impact on the professional development of the postdoctoral fellow. The fellow attended conferences and workshops, mentored undergraduate and graduate students, participated in a field campaign, helped to create a welcoming atmosphere at NCAR, served the scientific community through reviewing papers and proposals, and in general worked on outreach to the community to increase public engagement with science and our atmosphere.
